snippet.textDisplay: Dear Coke studio, I can not thank you more for producing / sharing this program. Especially when I noticed that the women are all from Goa! This is what we call real 'fusion'. But its obscene that you deliberately ignored the name of the two folk Instrumentalists  playing dotara and ektara. Why? No glamour? Very shameful!
snippet.textOriginal: Dear Coke studio, I can not thank you more for producing / sharing this program. Especially when I noticed that the women are all from Goa! This is what we call real 'fusion'. But its obscene that you deliberately ignored the name of the two folk Instrumentalists  playing dotara and ektara. Why? No glamour? Very shameful!

snippet.textDisplay:
@paritoshrjn  I dont understand the original coke studio part. Yes, it was started in Pakistan but it is owned by Coca Cola. Since it belongs to a corporation and not a country, is there an argument of originality? Doesn't Coke Studio cater to unPop music true to its soil? So tomorrow, this very idea can run in Kazhakistan, Istanbul or Morocco.
And I also don't subscribe to "your drummer", "them" etc. If we love music, we should by now alienate such divisions and unite as world citizens.
snippet.textOriginal:
@paritoshrjn  I dont understand the original coke studio part. Yes, it was started in Pakistan but it is owned by Coca Cola. Since it belongs to a corporation and not a country, is there an argument of originality? Doesn't Coke Studio cater to unPop music true to its soil? So tomorrow, this very idea can run in Kazhakistan, Istanbul or Morocco.
And I also don't subscribe to "your drummer", "them" etc. If we love music, we should by now alienate such divisions and unite as world citizens.
